Title.evidence: Methods: A randomised controlled trial was conducted

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned to either videolaryngoscope-guided or direct laryngoscope-guided DLT intubation.

Intervention.evidence: videolaryngoscope-guided or direct laryngoscope-guided DLT intubation

Objective.evidence: This study evaluates the effectiveness of videolaryngoscopes in thoracic airway management

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the success rate of DLT intubation on the first attempt, measured immediately post-intubation.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed using sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was applied to outcome assessors.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 200 participants were randomised: 100 to the videolaryngoscope group and 100 to the direct laryngoscope group, between January 2020 and June 2021.

Number_Analysed.evidence: In the intention-to-treat analysis, 98 participants in the videolaryngoscope group and 97 in the direct laryngoscope group were analysed.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The videolaryngoscope group showed a higher first-attempt success rate (mean difference = 12%, 95% CI 5% to 19%; p = 0.002).

Harms.evidence: Adverse events were reported in 3% of the videolaryngoscope group and 1% of the direct laryngoscope group, with mild severity.
